trans-unit.source: Displays an image on a mobile Web page.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image> class provides a way to choose an image file based on device characteristics.
For certain devices, you can specify built-in images by using a `symbol` : prefix as part of the URL in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image.ImageUrl%2A> property.
For more information, see the Device-Specific section of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image>.

If your application relies on cookieless sessions, or might receive requests from browsers that require cookieless sessions, using a tilde ("~") in a path can inadvertently result in creating a new session and potentially losing session data.
To set a property with a path such as ("~/path"), resolve the path using <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.ResolveUrl%2A>("~/path") before assigning it to the property.
Creates a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image"></xref> class.
Gets or sets the alternate text to display when an image is not available for the device.
The default value is an empty string ("").
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The alternate text appears in browsers that do not support images or where the image file is not available.
The alternate text to display when an image is not available for the device.
Gets or sets the URL of the image source for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image"></xref> control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

Because various devices provide a set of built-in pictures, such as images for a heart, sunshine, a book, a right arrow, and so on, by using a [\<DeviceSpecific>](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/6dca8eb9-d6f6-479a-abac-20fc9d485cc8) control within the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image> control, you can provide a wide variety of graphics that can be integrated into the devices themselves, as well as standard Web graphics.

For example, you can specify `symbol:63726` as the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image.ImageUrl%2A> property value for all devices that require WML markup, and Sunshine.gif as the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image.ImageUrl%2A> property value for HTML devices.

The exact resolution of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image.ImageUrl%2A> value is provided by an image adapter (such as <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.ChtmlImageAdapter>, <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.WmlImageAdapter>, or <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Adapters.XhtmlAdapters.XhtmlImageAdapter>).
The URL of the image source for the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image"></xref>
Gets or sets the target URL of the image.
The default value is an empty string ("").
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.

If your application relies on cookieless sessions, or might receive requests from browsers that require cookieless sessions, using a tilde ("~") in a path can inadvertently result in creating a new session and potentially losing session data.
To set a property with a path such as ("~/path"), resolve the path using <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.ResolveUrl%2A>("~/path") before assigning it to the property.
The target URL of the image.
Notifies the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image"></xref> object of a postback event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> that represents an optional event argument to be passed to the event handler.
Gets or sets the text displayed for a softkey when the Image has a <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image.NavigateUrl"></xref> property defined.
The default value is an empty `string`.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This property is used only for devices that support softkeys.
If this property is empty, the `Text` property of the control is used.
If the `Text` property is empty or its length is less than 9, the `Text` property is used for the softkey label.
The text displayed for a softkey when the image has a <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image.NavigateUrl"></xref> property defined.
For a description of this member, see <xref href="System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler.RaisePostBackEvent(System.String)"></xref>.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
This member is an explicit interface member implementation.
It can be used only when the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Image> instance is cast to an <xref:System.Web.UI.IPostBackEventHandler> interface.
Optional event argument to be passed to the event handler.
